title: Exponentially Faster Shortest Paths in the Congested Clique

sections.introduction:
Shortest paths computation is one of the most fundamental graph problems, and as such it has been studied extensively in various computational models. In this work we consider the problem of approximating shortest path distances in the Congested Clique model of distributed computing . This model attracts an increasing amount of attention over the last decade, due to its relation to practical parallel models such as MapReduce  and kğ‘˜k-machines .
The fast evolution of shortest path algorithms in the Congested Clique model

The above mentioned algorithms are all based on matrix multiplication.
An alternative natural approach for approximating APSP is obtained by the notion of multiplicative spanners, namely, sparse subgraphs that preserve all distances up to a small multiplicative stretch.
Specifically, by computing a sparse kğ‘˜k-spanner in the graph, and collecting its edges at each vertex, one immediately gets

The starting point of their algorithms is based on the Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)-approximation provided by spanners. This approximation is then iteratively improved by applying a tailored gradient descent procedure. Their algorithms also have the additional benefit of being implemented in the more stringent Broadcast Congested Clique model111In this model, each vertex is limited to send the same message to all other vertices in a given round.. In a very recent work, Censor-Hillel et al. [ref]3 presented poly-logarithmic time solutions for the more general problems of approximate multi-source shortest paths (MSSP) and APSP. The approach of [ref]3 is based on a clever reduction to sparse matrix multiplication algorithms from  [ref]3. This reduction is not immediate, for the following reason. The basic approach of using matrix multiplications to compute distances is based on starting with the input matrix of the graph Ağ´A and then iteratively square it Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log{n}) times.
Even if the original graph is sparse (e.g., with Oâ€‹(n3/2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›32O(n^{3/2}) edges), a single multiplication step might already result in a dense matrix. Since one needs to apply Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) multiplication steps, it is required to sparsify the intermediate matrices as well. To overcome this barrier, [ref]3 developed a rich tool-kit for distance computation, that includes hopset constructions, fast computation of the kğ‘˜k-nearest neighbours and more. The poly-logarithmic time complexity appears to be a natural barrier in the matrix multiplications based algorithms, from the following reason. Basically these algorithms work in iterations, where in iteration iğ‘–i, vertices learn about paths that have at most 2isuperscript2ğ‘–2^{i} edges, hence Î©â€‹(logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(\log n) iterations seem to be required in order to capture shortest paths with polynomial number of hops.
In this paper we ask if this barrier is indeed fundamental.
 Is it possible to provide (1+Ïµ)1italic-Ïµ(1+\epsilon)-approximation for SSSP and (2+Ïµ)2italic-Ïµ(2+\epsilon)-approximation for APSP in oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(\log n) rounds? Another plausible explanation for viewing the logarithmic time complexity as a natural barrier comes from the following observation.
The current state-of-the-art bound of many graph problems in the Congested Clique model is bounded from below by the
logarithm of their respective Local time complexities222In the Local model, only vertices that are neighbors in the input graph can communicate in a given round. The messages are allowed to be of unbounded size.. In the more restrictive, yet quite related model of MPC, this limitation was conditionally proven by Ghaffari, Kuhn and Uitto . Since the locality of the shortest path problem is linear, we reach again to the barrier of Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) rounds. Note that such guarantee is closer to (1+Ïµ)1italic-Ïµ(1+\epsilon)-approximation for long enough paths, which is much better than a multiplicative (2+Ïµ)2italic-Ïµ(2+\epsilon)-approximation, which raises the following question. Can we get near-additive approximation for APSP in sub-polynomial time?
